title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category of visitors, business facilitation visitors, who are aliens visiting the US temporarily to provide services. A business facilitation visitor is an alien visiting the US temporarily to provide services or receive management or technical training from a US entity. No alien may be admitted as a business facilitation visitor without meeting certain conditions. A business facilitation visitor is an alien who visits the US temporarily to provide services or receive management or technical training from a US entity. To be admitted as a business facilitation visitor, the alien must meet certain conditions, including being a national of a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat visa fraud. The alien must be certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat visa fraud and meet specific conditions to be admitted as a business facilitation visitor to the US, including using measures like machine-readable passports and biometric technology. The alien applies for a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B) and must meet specific conditions related to the provision of services. The alien applying for a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B) must meet conditions such as having all remuneration and expenses paid by the employer and possessing expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations. The alien applying for a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B) must have expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations and possess all required licenses to provide services in the United States. Conditions apply to the provision or receipt of management or technical training. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions for management or technical training. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions for management or technical training. The entity providing or receiving training must be affiliated with the United States entity through ownership, control, joint venture, or purchasing goods/services. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions for management or technical training. The training must be related to purchasing or selling goods/services from/to a United States entity, with all expenses paid by the employer. The alien must have at least 5 years of experience in management or management training and detailed knowledge to provide management training. All expenses related to the training will be paid by the employer. The alien must have at least 5 years of management experience, detailed knowledge of the employer's business operations, and hold a management level position within the employer to receive management training. The alien must have 5 years of management experience and hold a management level position within the employer to receive management training. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security under certain circumstances. The delay in completing services under a contract and the inability to replace the alien without further delays are reasons for extending the period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing professional services. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training is limited to 1 year. Additionally, a business facilitation visitor is not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment from nonimmigrant status. The business facilitation visitor is not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security can prohibit nationals from a country engaged in fraud from entering the US. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals of a country engaged in fraud from entering the US as business facilitation visitors for a specified period. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a US entity. A qualifying services contract is a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a United States entity, outlining the time period, duties, and payment provisions for the alien fulfilling the contract in the US. The duties to be performed by the alien in the United States must be outlined in the qualifying services contract. Additionally, provisions must state that the alien's remuneration and expenses will be paid by the foreign provider, and the United States entity will provide working conditions comparable to those of similarly situated providers of professional services. The alien must possess necessary credentials and licenses to provide services in the United States as outlined in the qualifying services contract. The foreign provider is responsible for ensuring the alien's credentials and providing the services covered by the contract. The foreign provider must ensure the alien's compliance with admission terms and return to their home country after the authorized period in the United States.
